awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Liquid Chromatograph QToF Mass Spectrometer to Support Research and Training at Hofstra University
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Hofstra University to support the acquisition of a liquid chromatograph quadrupole time-of-flight mass spectrometer (LC-MS) and a nitrogen generator. The acquisition brings the first high-resolution mass spectrometer to an academic institution in Nassau County (Pop: 1.36 million). LC-MS is an important analytical technique for separating and characterizing complex mixtures of chemical and biological molecules, and has broad applications across science and engineering. The instrument will be incorporated into multiple courses in the STEM curriculum at Hofstra University, providing undergraduates with exposure to this crucially important technology.  Outside the classroom, students will receive in-depth training in LC-MS through faculty-guided research across four disciplines at Hofstra and nearby Adelphi University and the State University of New York – Old Westbury. Hofstra and its partner institutions successfully recruit and train diverse student bodies through a variety of community outreach and support programs. Experience with cutting edge LC-MS instrumentation will benefit that diverse group of students when they seek employment or pursue graduate studies in STEM fields.  

The new LC-MS will greatly enhance research capabilities in biology, biochemistry, and biotechnology.  Research projects enabled by the instrument vary widely, from studying the occurrence and transformation of pollutants in environmental systems, to characterizing chemical modifications in RNA/protein complexes essential to mRNA transport. The instrument will be used to conduct proteomic analyses of protein export in polymicrobial communities and for metabolomic analyses of plant-microbe interactions of beachgrass and grapevines. It will be used to characterize newly synthesized molecules for studying fatty acid recycling and for investigating new approaches for carbon-carbon bond formation. The instrument will also be used for analyzing protein derivatization in the osteodifferentiation of stem cells and the dephosphorylation of signaling networks involved in cancer development. The results of these research efforts will be disseminated by students and faculty at scientific conferences, symposia, and in peer-reviewed publications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award funded the acquisition of a QToF LC-MS/MS instrument for use in undergraduate research, training, and education. A Waters Xevo G2-XS QToF coupled with an ACQUITY I-Class UPLC was setup at Hofstra University, making it the first high-resolution mass spectrometer at an academic institution in Nassau County, NY. In addition to serving researchers and students at Hofstra University, the instrument is also available to major users from nearby Adelphi University and SUNY-Old Westbury. This advanced analytic instrument enables users to precisely and accurately measure small molecules and biological molecules at trace levels, and supports activities in diverse scientific disciplines including chemistry, biology, physics, and engineering.

Research projects aided by the instrument that focus on small molecule analysis include: characterizing how sunlight transforms “emerging” chemicals of concern, including understudied pesticides and toxicants associated with tire-wear particles; monitoring the formation of toxic molecules in indoor air that could pose threats to human health; investigating the composition of gummies and CBD oils widely sold in smoke shops; and monitoring the synthesis of important organic compounds using cutting-edge green chemistry techniques designed to minimize and avoid toxic waste. Projects aided by the instrument that focus on biomolecules include: tracking the dephosphorylation of proteins in signaling networks that play an important role in cancer development; and characterizing keratin-related proteins that are important for hair, nail, and skin health, and that may have important bioengineering applications in drug delivery and tissue engineering. Results have been disseminated in national conference presentations, peer-reviewed publications, and grant applications.

Best practices have been implemented for training users, facilitating shared use by users from a variety of academic disciplines and institutions, and archiving data so that it is readily available to researchers.  Substantial difficulties were overcome in the initial setup and commissioning of the instrument, but we have continued to improve our workflows and have implemented a variety of effective quality control practices to detect instrument malfunctions and ensure that reliable data is collected.  To that end, we have also prepared a variety of guidance documents for onboarding new users and streamlining data analysis.

This instrument has been integrated into two undergraduate lab courses, Forensic Pharmacology: Analysis of Drugs and Drug Metabolites and Instrumental Analysis, offering students hands-on experience with cutting-edge technology. Undergraduate research students, including those from underrepresented groups in STEM, are also trained in sample processing, instrument operations, and data processing. This instrument is enabling diverse research and fostering new collaborations, enhancing teaching efforts, and providing crucial training for undergraduate students and researchers to prepare them for careers in academia, industry, and government laboratories.
